org.sustudio.concise.core.collocation

Class Collocate

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.sustudio.concise.core.collocation.Collocate
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class Collocate
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    Collocate is a word cooccurred near the node word. J. R. Firth (1957) introduced the term "collocations" for characteristic and frequently recurrent word combinations, arguing that the meaning and usage of a word (the node) can to some extent be characterised by its most typical collocates: "You shall know a word by the company it keeps" (Firth 1957, 179).

    Following the Firthian tradition (e.g. Sinclair 1991), a collocation is a combination of two words that exhibit a tendency to occur near each other in natural language, i.e. to cooccur. The cooccurrence of words here is defined as surfface cooccurrence (Evert 2007) where words are said to cooccur if they appear close to each other in running text, measured by the number of intervening word tokens. Surface cooccurrence is often, though not always combined with a node-collocate view, looking for collocates within the collocational spans around the instances of a given node word.

    Two kinds of association measures are computed in the Collocate, i.e. simple association measures and statistical association measures. A simple association measure interprets observed cooccurrence frequency O by comparison with the expected frequency E, and calculates an association score as a quantitative measure for the attraction between two words.

    A rigious statistical approach to measuring association is based on contingency tables representing the cross-classification of a set of items. However, the statistical interpretation of surface cooccurrence is slightly different from the normal contingency table (See the extended manuscript of Evert's (2007) Corpora and Collocations, pp. 27-28).

    Association measures can be divided into two general groups: measures of effect size (see getMI(), getMI3(), getOddsRatio() and getDice()) and measures of significance (see getZscore(), getTscore(), getSimpleLL(), getChiSquaredCorr() and getLogLikelihood()). The former ask the question "how strongly are the words attracted to each other?" (operationalised as "how much does observed cooccurrence frequency exceed expected frequency?"), while the latter as "how much evidence is there for a positive association between the words, no matter how small effect size is?" (operationalised as "how unlikely is the null hypothesis that the words are independent?"). The two approaches to measuring association are not entirely unrelated: a word pair with large "true" effect size is also more likely to show significant evidence against the null hypothesis in a sample. However, there is an important difference between the two groups. Effect-size measures typically fail to account for sampling variation and are prone to a low-frequency bias (small E easily leads to spuriously high effect size estimates, even for O=1 or O=2), while significance measures are often prone to a high-frequency bias (if O is sufficiently large, even a small relative difference between O and E, i.e. a small effect size, can be highly significant).

    Author:
    Kuan-ming Su.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Collocate

        public Collocate(java.lang.String word,
         long fn,
         long fc,
         long fnc,
         long Nc,
         long Ns)
        Constructor of a collocate that creates a collocation and its association measures (MI, MI3, simple-ll, Dice coefficient, odds ratio, z-score, t-score, chi-squaredcorr and log-likelihood). Association measures are basically based on Evert's (2007) extended manuscript of Corpora and Collocations (available on-line at http://cogsci.uni-osnabrueck.de/~severt/PUB/Evert2007HSK_extended_manuscript.pdf), except the expected value of simple association measures.

        For simple association measures, Evert (2007) suggests an approximation formula for expected value, E = k*f1*f2/N. The factor k represents the total span size, e.g. k=10 for a symmetric span of 5 words (L5, R5), k=4 for a span (L3, R1), and k=1 for simple bigrams (L0, R1).

        However, the span is not always fixed while running into the sentence boundary or paragraph boundary. To deal with such cases, the total number of words (tokens) in the sample Ns is considered to calculate the expected value. The formula thus turns into E = Ns*f1/N.

        PLEASE NOTE: Statistical association measures are not 100% accurate. There is a little error in the way Concise implements contingency table. Concise over calculates the cooccurrences of node-collocate pair in some circumstances. This is best illustrated with an example:

        He said please please please leave me alone.

        Here, the lexical item please co-occurs with leave three times within a window span of -3 to +3 words. In theory, the collocate please should be only counted once. However, Concise counts three occurrences of please in this sentence. As a result, the collocational strength of items which co-occur repeatedly with the node item will be higher than it should be. In extreme cases, where the collocate is found more often than the number of the running text containing the node-collocate pair, this will result in a mathematical error (calculation of logarithm of a negative number). These collocates will be displayed in the collocation table but no collocation value is given.

        Parameters:
        word - the collocate word.
        fn - marginal frequency of the node (i.e. number of occurrences of the node in the corpus, i.e. number of concordance lines).
        fc - marginal frequency of the collocate (i.e. number of occurrences of the collocate in the corpus).
        fnc - co-occurrence frequency of (node, collocate) pair. (i.e. number of co-occurrences of the node and the collocate within a given span).
        Nc - the total number of words (tokens) in the corpus.
        Ns - the total number of words (tokens) in the sample.

      • getMI

        public double getMI()
        Returns Mutual Information or MI score of the collocate.

        MI = log2(O/E)

        MI score is an effect-size measure.

        Returns:
        MI score of the collocate.

      • getMI3

        public double getMI3()
        Returns MI3 score of the collocate.

        MI3 = log2(O3/E)

        MI3 score is an effect-size measure.

        Returns:
        MI3 score of the collocate.

      • getZscore

        public double getZscore()
        Returns z-score of the collocate.

        z-score = (O-E)/sqrt(E)

        z-score is a significance measure.

        An absolute value |z| > 1.96 is generally considered sufficient to reject the null hypothesis, i.e. to provide significant evident for a (positive or negative) association; a more conservative threshold is |z| > 3.29.

        Returns:
        z-score of the collocate.

      • getTscore

        public double getTscore()
        Returns t-score of the collocate.

        t-score = (O-E)/sqrt(O)

        t-score is a significance measure.

        Returns:
        t-score of the collocate.

      • getSimpleLL

        public double getSimpleLL()
        Returns a simplified version of Dunning's (1993) log likelihood ratio.

        simple-ll = 2(O*log(O/E)-(O-E))

        simple-ll is two-sided. The cut-off threshold at alpha .95 should be |simple-ll| > 3.84.

        simple-ll is a significance measure.

        A reference table can be found at http://gautam.lis.illinois.edu/monkmiddleware/public/analytics/dunnings.html. 

         simple-ll      Percentage      Odds
 3.84           5%              1 in 20
 6.63           1%              1 in 100
 7.9            0.5%            1 in 200
 10.83          0.1%            1 in 1,000
 15.15          0.01%           1 in 10,000
 19.5           0.001%          1 in 100,000
 23.9           0.0001%         1 in a million
 37.3           0.0000001       1 in a billion
        Returns:
        simplified log likelihood ratio.

      • getDice

        public double getDice()
        Returns the Dice coefficient (Smadja et al. 1996) of the collocate.

        Dice = 2*O11/(R1+C1)

        Dice coefficient is an effect-size measure.

        Returns:
        the Dice coefficient (Smadja et al. 1996) of the collocate.

      • getOddsRatio

        public double getOddsRatio()
        Returns the odds ratio (Blaheta and Johnson 2001, 56) of the collocate.

        odds-ratio = log( (O11 + 1/2)(O22 + 1/2) / (O12 + 1/2)(O21 + 1/2) )

        Odds ratio is an effect-size measure.

        PLEASE NOTE: There is an error in the way Concise implements odds ratio. See #Collocate(String, long, long, long, long, long[], long[], long) or getLogLikelihood() for detailed explanation.

        Returns:
        the odds ratio of the collocate.

      • getChiSquaredCorr

        public double getChiSquaredCorr()
        Returns Yates' continuity-corrected version of chi-squared.

        chi-squaredcorr = N(|O11O22-O12O21| - N/2)2 / R1R2C1C2

        chi-squaredcorr is a significance measure.

        PLEASE NOTE: There is an error in the way Concise implements contingency table. See #Collocate(String, long, long, long, long, long[], long[], long) or getLogLikelihood() for detailed explanation.

        Returns:
        Yates' continuity-corrected version of chi-squared.

      • getLogLikelihood

        public double getLogLikelihood()
        Returns Dunning's (1993) log-likelihood ratio.

        log-likelihood = 2ΣOijlog(Oij/Eij)

        log-likelihood is a significance measure.

        PLEASE NOTE: There is an error in the way Concise implements Dunning's log-likelihood ratio. In principle, the calculation should be strictly binary and the above formula therefore does not contains the variable "window span". This is best illustrated with an example:

        He said please please please leave me alone.

        Here, the lexical item please co-occurs with leave three times within a window span of -3 to +3 words. In theory, the collocate please should be only counted once. However, Concise counts three occurrences of please in this sentence. As a result, the collocational strength of items which co-occur repeatedly with the node item will be higher than it should be. In extreme cases, where the collocate is found more often than the number of the running text containing the node-collocate pair, this will result in a mathematical error (calculation of logarithm of a negative number). These collocates will be displayed in the collocation table but no collocation value is given.

        Returns:
        log-likelihood.

      • getFreq

        public long getFreq()
        Returns the surface co-occurrences of the (node, collocate) pair.
        Returns:
        the surface co-occurrences of the (node, collocate) pair.
